awd_titl_txt: Algebraic Structures over Fields of Functions
awd_abstract_narration:
The project concerns the use of geometric ideas to study problems in algebra.  Algebra and geometry are generally regarded as separate areas of mathematics.  Nevertheless, it can be very fruitful to use them in combination, as observed by Descartes through the use of graphs.  In geometry, one can often study global properties of spaces by examining the local behavior of the spaces.  Using the connection between algebra and geometry, it is sometimes possible to study problems in algebra as well, by reducing global questions to ones that are viewed as more local.  The goals of the project involve generalizing this approach to new situations, including higher dimensional spaces, in order to solve open problems that arise in several areas of algebra.

The first goal is to generalize to higher dimensions the method of field patching that has so far been developed only in the context of varieties of dimension one, over a complete discretely valued field.  The second goal is to use this generalization to obtain local-global principles for algebraic structures over higher dimensional function fields.  Such structures include central simple algebras, torsors under linear algebraic groups, and quadratic forms.  These local-global principles in turn are expected to lead to results on numerical field invariants such as the period-index bound and the u-invariant.  The activities of the proposal will also have broader impacts in terms of mentoring, enhancing the research infrastructure, and communicating mathematics outside of academia.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research funded in this grant concerns the study of algebraic 
structures by means of geometric methods.  By using a geometric 
approach, the research aimed to go further than would be possible by 
working just algebraically.  The algebraic structures we considered 
arise in the context of a field of functions on a curve or a higher 
dimensional space.  A key strategy was to obtain a global understanding 
of these algebraic objects by examining the spaces locally, through what 
are known as local-global principles.

In this grant, we focused especially on objects known as torsors, which 
correspond to a wide variety of algebraic structures such as quadratic 
forms and central simple algebras.  By drawing on a number of methods, 
we examined whether local-global principles hold for torsors that are 
defined over semi-global fields, which include function fields of curves 
over local fields.  In the case of torsors under tori, and more 
generally under reductive groups, we obtained explicit computations of 
the obstruction to a local-global principle holding.  In particular, we 
were able to show in many cases that this principle holds, while in 
other cases we measured the extent to which the 
principle does not hold.

Another research direction in this grant concerned differential 
equations, which play important roles in physics and engineering.  To a 
linear differential equation one can associate an object known as its 
differential Galois group, and the structure of this group determines 
whether the equation can be solved explicitly.  It was conjectured that 
the absolute differential Galois group is free over the complex numbers. 
  Using our patching methods, we proved that this is the case, and more 
generally did so over any algebraically closed field of infinite 
transcendence degree over the rational numbers.

The research on this grant also included work on extending our patching 
methods to higher dimensional spaces, in order to be able to obtain 
local-global principles and information on the behavior of algebraic 
structures in those contexts.  We achieved this in the affine case, with 
progress toward doing the same in the projective case.

Beyond the research results obtained, this grant helped train and 
provide professional development for students and postdocs.  This 
included supervision and guidance of both graduate students and 
undergraduates on research projects, as well as research done in 
conjunction with postdoctoral fellows whom we were training.  In 
addition, the PI organized a workshop for female undergrads who were 
interested in pursuing graduate studies in mathematics, and another such 
workshop for undergraduates from various underrepresented groups.  We 
also participated in our department's Bridge program for students
who are from underrepresented groups; on panels aimed at preparing 
undergraduates to apply to Ph.D. programs; and in discussion sessions on 
equitable teaching practices.  In addition, the investigators gave 
in-person and remote talks about the research conducted on this grant in 
order to disseminate the results; had meetings with research 
collaborators; and posted and submitted research manuscripts on the 
results of this grant, which have since been accepted for publication.
